sec.title: Background
sec.p: For the past 15 years, an innovative curriculum named Formation PARTENAIRES has been advancing patient partnership in interprofessional education (IPE) at Université de Montréal. The aim of this article is to describe, from the perspective of patients themselves, the changing role of patients within this training programme.

sec.title: Approach
sec.p: The PARTENAIRES programme is a mandatory undergraduate IPE curriculum implemented across 13 healthcare and social services disciplines, involving over 5000 students and 125 patient partners annually. The programme's evolution has been marked by increasing patient leadership and is now co‐chaired by a patient partner and a healthcare professional, with patients involved at all levels (design, delivery, assessment and improvement).

sec.title: Evaluation
sec.p: Key developments in patients' relationships with other stakeholders involved in the PARTENAIRES programme are highlighted. With students, patients have transitioned from providing one‐off, idealised testimonials to sustaining reflexive, real conversations that bridge the student‐patient gap. With academic disciplines, patient partners that were initially paired based on matching with their lived experience are now paired more flexibly to foster a universal educational contribution and support interdisciplinary learning. With clinical co‐facilitators, the patients' role has evolved from reactive participation during workshops to proactive co‐construction, promoting the democratisation of exchanges and shared responsibility for the programme's educational content.

sec.title: Implications
sec.p: Sustained institutional trust and long‐term involvement have enabled patient partners to become central co‐creators in the PARTENAIRES curriculum. Patients' transversal role fosters innovation and cross‐disciplinary collaboration, illustrating that significant cultural change in IPE emerges through openness, adaptability and the time to grow together.

sec.title: Background
sec.p: In 2010, a new interprofessional education (IPE) programme was launched at Université de Montréal in Quebec, Canada. This programme was one of the first to offer a shared curriculum across different disciplines (n = 4: medicine, nursing, occupational therapy, pharmacy), using a small‐group learning model [1]. Shortly after its creation, a pilot project was introduced to include a patient partner alongside a healthcare professional to co‐facilitate the programme's cross‐disciplinary workshops. The objective was to help students make the necessary transition from paternalism and patient‐centredness towards a partnership approach, the notion of which had been defined, promoted and gradually integrated by the first patients involved in the programme themselves [2]. Students immediately valued this approach, and patient partners were officially integrated and remunerated. This was a groundbreaking educational innovation, as the few existing instances of active patient involvement in professional education at the time tended to be one‐off educational experiences aimed at a single group of learners [3, 4].

Since then, much has changed in the field and especially for us patients. The purpose of this article is to describe the evolution of patient involvement in this unique IPE curriculum, now called the Formation PARTENAIRES programme. In doing so, we also aim to share a distinctive perspective—our own, as patient partners—to tell the story of this transformation and the key insights we have gained along the way.

disp-quote.p: The purpose of this article is to describe the evolution of patient involvement in this unique IPE curriculum, now called the Formation PARTENAIRES programme.

sec.title: Approach
sec.p: The PARTENAIRES training programme is an undergraduate curriculum consisting of three one‐credit courses. It is a mandatory component for students across 13 healthcare and social services disciplines at our university (audiology, dental medicine, kinesiology, medicine, nursing, nutrition, occupational therapy, optometry, speech therapy, pharmacy, physiotherapy, psychoeducation and social work), spanning six faculties and schools. Each year, the programme engages approximately 5200 students, 25 course teachers (lecturers or faculty, some of whom are not practicing clinicians), 125 patient partners and 125 clinical co‐facilitators. To our knowledge, no other university‐based IPE programme operates at this scale.

disp-quote.p: Each year, the programme engages approximately 5200 students, 25 course teachers …, 125 patient partners and 125 clinical co‐facilitators.

sec.p: Pedagogically, the courses are geared towards the gradual learning of interprofessional collaborative practice in partnership with patients (including family caregivers and significant others). The first course introduces patient partnership as the foundation of collaboration, emphasising the patient as the primary team member. The second introduces collaborative work, while the third explores collaboration in complex, real‐world situations. Each course follows a similar structure: (1) an introductory activity conducted within each discipline; (2) asynchronous online modules; and (3) a cross‐disciplinary small‐group workshop (see Figure 1). Synchronous sessions, lasting 3 h each, are led by duos of co‐facilitators that include a patient partner and a course teacher for introductory activities or a clinical co‐facilitator for cross‐disciplinary workshops.

caption.p: Overview of the Formation PARTENAIRES curriculum.

sec.p: Initially, the PARTENAIRES programme was managed by a logistics team and a senior academic leader. Progressive and sustained patient involvement led to the creation of a patient vice‐president position. During the COVID‐19 pandemic, patient partners played a key role in sustaining the programme through the transition to online learning and as clinical co‐facilitators faced increased demands in care settings [5, 6]. This commitment prompted the creation of a patient co‐president position. Today, the programme is co‐chaired by a patient partner and a professional. Figure 2 depicts key milestones in the programme's evolution.

sec.p: Patient partners like us are now involved at all levels of the programme, from start to finish. All educational content is co‐developed and co‐delivered, except in the first course where we patient partners independently facilitate cross‐disciplinary workshops. Evaluation and improvement committees for each course are co‐led by a patient and a course teacher. Over the past 3 years, the curriculum has been fully redesigned in partnership with patients and in line with updated guidelines on collaborative practice [7].

sec.title: Evaluation
sec.p: Shifting relationships: Significant changes have occurred in our relationships with other key stakeholders of the PARTENAIRES programme—students, the participating academic programmes and clinical co‐facilitators—that reflect the evolution of our role as patient partners in IPE. Table 1 provides additional information on the key shifts mentioned. Our institutional research ethics committee assessed this article and confirmed that ethics approval was not required since it was not the result of a research project but a sharing of experience, and since no human participants were involved.

caption.p: Key shifts in the role of patient partners within the PARTENAIRES training programme.

Facilitating rehearsal, integrity and reproducibility of patients' contributions

list-item.p: Exposing students more deeply to the behind‐the‐scenes of a patient's life, broadening the scope of what they may consider clinically relevant

Opening ‘spaces of courage’ to discuss some of the invisible struggles of students and patients, for the benefit of all

td.p: Role: Being paired with an academic discipline on the basis of lived experience with the corresponding profession

list-item.p: Fostering mutual understanding and tight pedagogical synergy within each discipline
Facilitating recognition of the patient's presence as legitimate and relevant by students and teachers—and by patients themselves

Enabling the continuous presence of a patient perspective despite sudden changes in patient availability
Facilitating the acquisition and transfer of interdisciplinary knowledge

Grounding educational content more firmly in lived experience and reflexivity

sec.title: The Evolution of Our Relationship With Students
sec.p: Over the past 15 years, we have moved from delivering one‐off, static testimonials to establishing sustained and reflexive conversations with students that mobilise our experiences in dynamic, fluid ways [8]. This led to gradual distancing from our initial postures of promoting ideal patient partnership, as students could more readily question and challenge our discourses (see Table 1). Anchoring our interactions with students in real, imperfect and messy experiences shaped by the feelings, implications and repercussions of living with illness has also allowed us to draw unsuspected and valuable parallels between our care journeys and students' learning paths. We have realised that students could be as vulnerable during their training as we often are in our dealings with the healthcare system. We feel that such a no‐holds‐barred approach to exchanges better enables students to experience their first moments of genuine partnership with patients, hopefully planting the seed for their future professional practice.

disp-quote.p: We have realised that students could be as vulnerable during their training as we often are in our dealings with the healthcare system.

sec.title: The Evolution of Our Relationship With Academic Disciplines Through Within‐Programme Activities
sec.p: At first, patients participated in the PARTENAIRES programme only during cross‐disciplinary workshops, while introductory activities were led solely by course teachers. In 2017, the Tandem Patient role was created to involve patients earlier in each course and allow them to co‐facilitate these initial sessions. Working with the same student cohorts over 3 years, Tandem Patients ensured a longitudinal and coherent perspective across the whole PARTENAIRES curriculum—something not possible with the frequent turnover of course teachers.

disp-quote.p: Working with the same student cohorts over 3 years, Tandem Patients ensured a longitudinal and coherent perspective across the whole PARTENAIRES curriculum—something not possible with the frequent turnover of course teachers.

sec.p: Initially, each Tandem Patient was paired with a discipline aligned with their lived experience. For example, a patient with speech‐language issues would work with the speech‐language therapy programme. However, logistical issues such as last‐minute withdrawals forced us to adopt a more flexible pairing approach (see Table 1). This shift revealed that our added value extended beyond a specific clinical reality, as educational objectives were still achieved, and student engagement remained high. Exposure to multiple disciplines also gave us unique insight into differences in how the introductory activities were delivered, unlike course teachers who only teach them within their own discipline. With our growing experience, we actively contributed to reshaping these activities, collaborating with various course teachers to adapt content and enhance student learning.

sec.title: The Evolution of Our Relationship With Clinical Co‐Facilitators Through Cross‐Disciplinary Workshops
sec.p: In the early years of our involvement with the PARTENAIRES programme, our first contact with clinical co‐facilitators was limited to an email exchange aimed at establishing the basics of facilitation. Clinical co‐facilitators spontaneously took on the role of managing the workshop, structuring the session by introducing topics, managing time and speaking turns and closing the discussion. We, on the other hand, played mostly a reactive role, sharing snippets of our lived experience and intervening mainly at the clinician's invitation. As we gained confidence and pedagogical expertise, a more balanced dynamic gradually emerged (see Table 1). We have proposed adjustments and now fully take part in discussions with students and clinical co‐facilitators, taking the lead when we see fit. Furthermore, the PARTENAIRES team now strategically pairs newly integrated clinical co‐facilitators with senior patient partners. In these instances, we are the ones welcoming and familiarising clinical co‐facilitators with the workshops' format, content, and tools.

disp-quote.p: The PARTENAIRES team now strategically pairs newly integrated clinical co‐facilitators with senior patient partners.

sec.title: Implications
sec.p: The relational shifts described above reflect how we patient partners have become true pillars of co‐creation and co‐facilitation of the PARTENAIRES curriculum, sharing responsibility for its educational content alongside course teachers and clinical co‐facilitators. What made this breakthrough possible? While many factors undoubtedly played a role, we would like to highlight two key elements.

sec.title: Ongoing Commitment and Trust
sec.p: A strong commitment by institutional partners from the outset, sustained through the challenges encountered, has been essential. The Faculty of Medicine's Patient Partner Office at Université de Montréal has played a key role, recruiting all the patient partners, offering training and providing ongoing support throughout the evolution of our roles [2]. This continuity allowed mutual trust to be nurtured, leading us to gain confidence, find our place and dare to experiment! This trust fostered creativity and boldness in our continuous improvement processes. Some of us patients have now been with the PARTENAIRES programme longer than most course teachers. Our longstanding involvement enabled us to bring a central element to the PARTENAIRES curriculum: transversality.

disp-quote.p: A strong commitment by institutional partners from the outset, sustained through the challenges encountered, has been essential.

sec.p: Together with the PARTENAIRES team, we are just beginning to recognise the educational value of having Tandem Patients engage across multiple academic programmes, much like bees pollinating across disciplines. Through sustained and interdisciplinary engagement, PARTENAIRES patients are developing a unique, longitudinal and transversal expertise in IPE that few other educators hold. The parallel with healthcare is striking: It is often us patients who navigate across silos, driving collaboration and witnessing blind spots in the system.

sec.title: Acknowledging the Journey
sec.p: We hope readers appreciate the journey we have undertaken with the PARTENAIRES team. It has not been a smooth or linear path. Much of our progress came through trial and adjustment—learning from each other and allowing ourselves to make productive missteps as a result of bold actions. The level of partnership implementation we have reached probably cannot be replicated elsewhere instantly. Cultural transformation—for students, teachers, administrators and patients—varies in form and takes time. We must give ourselves time to ‘grow together’ [9].

disp-quote.p: Much of our progress came through trial and adjustment—learning from each other and allowing ourselves to make productive missteps as a result of bold actions.

sec.p: The evolving role of patient partners required the acquisition of new skills. Delivering a well‐rehearsed testimony is one thing; facilitating dynamic, unpredictable sessions is another. But this shift mirrors real‐life situations, where things cannot be fully controlled. This collective journey remains fraught with challenges. With 13 disciplines involved, each with its own language and approach, finding a functional balance requires continuous adjustment processes. The PARTENAIRES programme has regularly changed pedagogically and operationally to seek better ways to work together.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This article aimed to highlight, through the patient's voice, the evolution of patient involvement in the PARTENAIRES programme. A forthcoming paper will detail the significant pedagogical impacts of this evolution, including on the quality of educational experiences, incorporating the voices of the other actors engaged in the co‐construction process. However, our key takeaway is the importance of trusting the collaborative process itself, emerging from ongoing dialogue between patients, educators, professionals and students independently of the outcomes.

Reflecting on our modest beginnings as a fragile pilot project—when we had to continually justify the inclusion of patients in professional training—to the unparalleled IPE programme co‐chaired by a patient that we have become, we feel immense pride and gratitude. With the PARTENAIRES programme's 15th anniversary behind us, we remain committed to its ongoing evolution in demonstrating that patient partnership should be at the heart of all collaborative practices and that we have so much to learn from one another.
